sp.l: Ah pardon me. My heart begot a thought
At their departure, which had been of force
To have strained a tear or two from my moist eye.
How like was he to Eustace! he to Guy!

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: A leaden weight of grief lies at my heart,
And I could wish myself were banished too,
To bear them in their sorrows company.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: These, for examples sake, must be removed,
And though their absence will much weaken us ,
Yet we had rather put us in Gods guard,
Lessening our own strength, then to bear with that
Which might in time lead to our overthrow.
March forward Lords; our love we will defer.
Prince Tancred, till our wars chief heat be spent,
Keep still this beauteous Lady in your Tent.

div2.stage: Exeunt. flourish Manent two Ladies.

sp.speaker: Fren. Lad.
sp.l: My Lord is banished, what shall poor I do?
There is no way, but I must after too.
But ere I go, some cunning I must use,
To make this Lady my Lords love refuse.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Fair youth, why have you singled me alone?
Is it to share joy, or partake my moan?

sp.speaker: Fren. Lad.
sp.l: Whether you please.
Invention help me now,
To bring her out of love with my sweet Lord,
For should she love him I were quite undone.
Madam, in faith, how many suitors have you?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: More than I wish I had: First, the French General.

sp.speaker: Fren. Lad.
sp.l: O God, I fear, I think I am accursed.
She loves him best, because she names him first.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: The English Robert, County Palatine;
Two Gentlemen that took me in the woods;
One is now banished, but the other still
Stays in the Army; then, the Bulloigne Duke,

sp.speaker: Fren. Lad.
sp.l: And which of all these is the properest man?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I'faith let me hear thy judgment.

sp.speaker: Fren. Lad.
sp.l: Prince Robert is a gallant Gentlemen:
But the French Lord uncomely, and unshaped.
Tancred is a proper man, but the French Lord,
He hath no making, no good shape at all.
I could not love a man of his complexion:
I would not have him if I were a Lady,
Had he more Crowns than Caesar conquered.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I see no such defects in that French Lord.

sp.speaker: Fren. Lad.
sp.l: Aye, Aye, it is so. Upon my life she loves him.
I must devise some plot, or they will use
Some means to meet, and marry out of hand.
Lady, he was my Master, but believe me,
He is the most insatiate man for women,
That ever breathed; nay, Madam, which is more,
He loves variety, and delights in change.
And I heard him say, should he be married,
He would make his wife a cuckquean.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Why though he do; it is virtue in a woman,
If she can bear his imperfections.

sp.speaker: Fren. Lad.
sp.l: Upon my life they are made sure already,
She is pleased with any imperfections.
What should I do?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Now fair youth, list to me,
I will acquaint thee with a secrecy.
These Lords so trouble me with their vain suites,
That I am tired and wearied, and resolve
To steal away in secret from the Camp.

sp.speaker: Fren. Lad.
sp.l: My Guy is gone, and she would follow him:
I must prevent it, or else lose my love.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Wilt thou consort me, bear me company,
And share with me in joy and misery?

sp.speaker: Fren. Lad.
sp.l: Madam I will. She loves him, and no wonder.
I will go, be it but to keep them still asunder.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Then from their Tents this night we will steal away,
And through the wide woods and the Forests stray.

div2.stage: Exeunt. Florish. Enter Soldan, Sophie, Tvrnvs, Moretes, Drummes, Ensignes, and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Then your reports sound naught but death and war.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: The Christians would not lend an ear to peace.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Since they demean themselves so honourably,
This earth shall give them honourable graves.

sp.speaker: Tvr.
sp.l: By pride herself are their proud Ensigns borne:
War in their tongues sits, in their faces scorn.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Our resolutions shall control base fears.
We are proud as they; our swords shall answer theirs.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Didst thou deliver our strict Embassy?

sp.speaker: Tvr.
sp.l: I did, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Did they not quake to hear it?

sp.speaker: Tvr.
sp.l: No more than Rocks shake with a puff of breath,
They come resolved, and not in fear of death.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Looked they not pale?

sp.speaker: Tvr.
sp.l: With fury, not with fear.
They were mad, because your forces were not there.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Did you not dash their spirits? sell not their eyes.
Down to the earth, when thou didst speak of us?
Went not a fearful murmur through their Host,
When thou didst number our unnumbered power?
Did not their faint swords tremble in their hands,
At that name Sultan?

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Or when thou namedest me,
My power, my strength, my matchless chivalry:
Fell they not flat upon the earth with fear?

sp.speaker: Tvr.
sp.l: No, but their proud hearts bounded in their breasts,
Their plumes flew bravely on their golden crests:
And they were ready to have fallen at jar,
Which of them first should with the Persian war.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: There was no tongue but breathed defiance forth:
I could not see a face but menaced death:
No hand, but brandished a victorious sword.
They all cry Battle, Battle, peace defy,
And not a heart but promised victory.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: There is not an heart shall scape our tyranny,
Since they provoke our indignation,
Like the vast Ocean shall our courage rise,
To drown their pride, and all their powers surprise.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: My Scimitar is like the bolt of Jove,
That never toucheth but it strikes with death.
O how I long, till we with spears in rests,
Strike out the lightning from their high-plumed crests.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: I would burn off this beard in such a flame,
As I could kindle with my puissant blows:
Yet the least hair I value at more worth
Than all the Christian Empire.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Speak, brave Sultan,
Shall our barred horses clime yond Mountain tops,
And bid them battle where they pitch their Tents.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Courage cries, on; but good advice saith, stay.
Experience bids us fight another way.
Why should we tire our Troupes in search of them,
That with audacious boldness seek out us?
Let us stand to receive them when they come,
And with a grove of Pikes growing on this earth
Where now no tree appears, toss up their bodies,
Whose courses by your strong arms kept aloof,
May hang like bloody pendants on your staves.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: O sight best pleasing to the Persian gods!

sp.speaker: Tvr.
sp.l: In the skies forehead shall the bright Sun stand
Amazed to view that glorious spectacle,
And with the pleasing sight forget his way,
To grace our Trophy with perpetual day.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: But how shall we receive their armed Troops?
What special order will your grace assign
To them that shall command your Companies?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: It shall be thus. This way the Christians march,
The body of our Host shall stay behind,
To be a strength to fair Jerusalem.
But we with certain soldiers secretly,
Will lie in ambush: The great Persian Sophy,
With Turnus, and a chief command of men,
Shall guard that way: myself, and thou Morates
Will keep this passage with a troupe select,
To seize on their forerunners, scouts, and spies.
Assist us fate, ere-long the world shall know
Our glories by the Christians overthrow.
This is my Quarter: these my men shall be.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Morates, thou and these shall follow me.

div2.stage: Exeunt. Enter Robert of Normandy.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O whether will blind love conduct my steps?
Prince Tancreds Dear, and English Roberts Joy,
Is fled in secret, and hath left our Tents.
Thus like an Errant and Adventurous Knight,
I have left the Host to follow her fair search,
And durst not trust the air with my intent.
This way, they say, she went; the Camp is secure.
This way unknown, in secret I pursue her.

div2.stage: Enter Charles.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: This way my love went like a shooting star,
Whose blazing train doth guild the firmament.
Such glorious beauty adds she to the way,
Making the dark night-paths, shine bright as day.
Ye honoured Arms farewell, and Camp adieu,
I do forsake myself her to pursue.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Behold a traveller! I will enquire
If chance hath cast his eye upon my love.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: I was about to ask of yonder man,
Whether her beauty had enriched his sight:
But it is my rival Robert; Charles obscure thee.
For should he see thee, he would quickly judge
What Adamant had drawn me to these woods.
One case I see hath made us errants both.
To be found wandering thus I should be loath.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Love that drew me, hath drawn that knight along
Being but a child, a Giant is not so strong.

div2.stage: Enter Soldan, Moretes, and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Stand Christians, by your Crosses on your breasts
Ye are marked for death, and base destruction.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: What are ye, that, like cowards, with such odds
Assault us thus unfurnish for the wars.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: I am the Sultan; these my men at arms,
That lie to intercept you, and prepare
For your accursed lives this fatal snare.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: The Sultan, the grand enemy to Christ,
The devils Lieutenant, viceroy under him!
Brave English Robert, since our frowning stars
Have brought us to this narrow exigent,
And trained us hither with a chain of love
To perish by the swords of Infidels:
Stand foot to foot.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Tush, I am Pagans swords proof, and my stars,
Have marked me for a Conqueror in these wars.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Upon them, soldiers; pity they despise,
Scarce can the world afford a richer prize.

div2.stage: Alarum. They fight, and are both taken.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Thou glorious eye of heaven, be ever blind:
Mask thy bright face in clouds eternally:
Dark vapours and thick mists thy front embrace
And never shine to look on my disgrace.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: A prisoner, Robert! this my comfort be:
He makes me bound that best can set me free.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Take them to guard, this entrance to our wars
Is full of spirit, and begets much hope.
We will not yet examine what ye are,
Till tortures wring it from your slavish tongues.
That done, your bloods these champaines shall imbrue
Mean time we will wait for more of your loose crew.

div2.stage: Enter Gvy with his Shield, and a Page brings his Sword and Target: in each of his hands a Pollax.

sp.speaker: Gvy.
sp.l: I am turned wild man since I used these Forests:
And I have won more weapons in these woods,
From Outlaws, whom my sword hath vanquished,
Than I can carry on my back with ease.
I have swords, targets, Pikes, and Partisans,
pole-axes, maces, clubs, and horsemens staves,
Darts, halberds, long swords, Pistols, Petronels,
All which I have conquered. At this Mountain ridge
Two villains with these weapons set upon me:
But with my sword I made them turn their heels,
And leaves these Trophies which I thus support,
And bear upon my shoulders Conqueror-like,
What? do I see an ambush? by their arms
They should be Pagans: Robert prisoner!
With him a Christian Leader! O my God,
Thou hast either brought me to revive my name
By rescuing these, or here to die with shame.
Come life, come death; a banished man will try,
To live with honour, or with honour die.
Robert break from thy guard, make them dismayed,
Receive these weapons, God hath sent thee aid.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: God, and Saint George.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Now by the Sultans Crown,
If I can wield this weapon, he shall down.

sp.speaker: Gvy.
sp.l: The Christians God for us.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: What, are they free?
Alarum Drums, the heathen powers for me.

div2.stage: They fight; the Pagans are beaten off, Guy departs suddenly.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Some Angel in the habit of a Knight,
Hath rescued us: such heavy downright blows
Could never come from any mortal arm.
For every blow he reached, was certain death.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: What is that power, if heavenly power he be,
That we may laud and praise his Deity?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Departed on a sudden ere we know,
To whom our freedoms, and our lives we owe!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: By that inscription graven on his shield,
We may perhaps descry him in the camp
Cease admiration then; let these events,
Hasten our steps back to survey our Tents.

div2.stage: Enter seuerally Godfrey, and Tancred.

sp.speaker: Tanc.
sp.l: Godfrey!

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: Tancred!

sp.speaker: Tanc.
sp.l: Well met my Lords in these unpeopled paths:
What hath your love made you to leave the field.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: Godfrey never dreamt to have met with Tancred here
The Lady that hath fled from our chaste love,
(Whom Tancred I do more affectionate,
Because she much resembles my fair sister)
Hath caused me so much to forget myself,
And play the wanderer in these unknown woods.
But soft, that drum should speak the Pagans tongue:
I fear we are betrayed, Aye, Aye, it is so:
Tancred, we are round compassed by the foe.

div2.stage: Soldan, Sophie, and Souldiers, encompasse the Christian Princes: Enter Evstace, and set them free.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Thank me for this; for, next the Almighty Powers,
I have been the means to save your desperate lives.
Now, Christian Princes, I am quit with you
For all the grace you have done me in the Camp;
And now you owe me for my banishment.
And though you have exiled me from your Tents,
You have not power to keep me from the wars.
Upon this shield I bear the Grocers Arms,
Unto which Trade I was enroled and bound:
And like a strange Knight, I will aid the Christians,
Thou Trade which didst sustain my poverty,
Didst helpless, help me; though I left thee then,
Yet that the world shall see I am not ingrate,
Or scorning that, which gave my fortunes breath,
I will enlarge these Arms, and make their name
The original and life of all my fame.
But I am tired with travail, Shield lie there,
O that I could but see that lusty spirit,
My arch-foe, rival in my banishment,
To be revenged, and end my hostile hate!
I will dream I fight with him to ease my spleen,
And in that thought I lay me on this green.

div2.stage: Sleep Enter Gvy with a paper and his Shield.

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: Arms ye are full of hope and sweet success,
The famous Art, whose honoured badge ye are,
First, when I lived amongst London prentices,
Gave me an honest and a pleasant life,
Now in these woods have won me fame and honour:
And I have rescued Princes with this shield:
And Princes are indebted to these Arms.
And if I live , in memory of this
Within their fair Hall shall this Escutcheon hang,
Till some smooth pen Historize my name,
What object is that? A Knight a sleep or dead?
O it is the Base, and ground of all my hate;
I will kill the villain: O dishonoured thought!
Art thou not son unto the Bullen Duke,
And canst thou hatch dishonour? Arch-foe live.
I scorn advantage, should I fight with Mars.
He bears this shield I will exchange with his,
And leave a Motto written in mine own
Shall make him quake to read. Be swift my pen,
To affright his sense when he shall wake again.
It is done. Then go with me and mine stay here,
Which in despite of thee, base Knight, I wear.

div2.stage: Exit.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: The hours have overrun me with swift pace,
And time hath fastened to him swallows wings.
Come sword, come Shield; but soft, thou art a stranger,
And pardon me good shield, I know thee not.
What have we here?
Ask not who that Shield doth owe,
For he is thy mortal foe:
And where ere he sees that shield,
City, Borough, Grove, or Field,
He that bears it, bears his bane,
By his hand he must be slain.
Thine, in spite of thee, he will bear,
(If thou darest) his Escutcheon wear.
He writ this, that thy shield will keep,
And might have slain thee being asleep.
It is a fine fellow; by this light, he is
An honest Rogue, and hath a good conceit.
Wear it? I will wear it. If I do not! well,
He needed not to have put in the word (Dare)
For I dare: dare I?, he shall see I dare.
Belike he fears I dare not challenge mine.
Were it fastened to the arm of Beelzebub,
I would fight with him with firebrands for my shield.
But dares he wear mine? On my life he dares:
I love him like my brother for this act:
And I will bear this shield with as much pride,
As sate I in a chariot by Jove's side.
Shine bright my Stars, to do me some fair grace,
Bring us to meet in some auspicious place.

div2.stage: Enter the Ladies flying, pursued by the Clowne.

sp.speaker: CloW.
sp.p:
Nay you cowardly Lady, that run away from
the Camp, and dare not stand to it, I am glad I have light on
you; choose your weapon, choose your weapon; I am a Soldier,
and a martial man, and I will offer you the right of
Arms: If you vanquish me, I will be your captive, if you be cast
down I will carry you back prisoner.

sp.speaker: Fren. Lad.
sp.l: I wear a weapon that I dare not draw:
Fie on this womanish fear, what shall I do.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Some of my fathers spirit revives in me,
Give me thy weapon, boy, and thou shalt see,
I for us both will win sweet liberty.

sp.speaker: CloW.
sp.p:
I was never so overreached; and, but for shame,
and that I am a man at arms, I would run away, and take me
to my legs. Have at thee sweet Lady.

div2.stage: As they fight, Evstace comes in:

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Base villain, darest thou offer violence
Unto a Lady; stay, maintain thy challenge.

sp.speaker: CloW.
sp.p:
You think you have a fool in hand; no by my
faith, not I. If you have any business to the Camp, farewell,
I am running thither as fast as I can.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Mount up my soul, unto the heighth of joy!
Saving my foe, whose honoured shield I bear,
None living did I more desire to meet.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Saving those Christian Lords that seek my love
None living did I more desire to shun.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Well met, brave Saint, in these unpeopled paths,
Fear no rude force, for I am civil borne,
Descended from a Princely parentage,
And though an exile from the Christians Camp,
Yet in my heart I wear the Cross of Christ,
Even in as deep a crimson as the best.
Love me, though I am Landless, and remote
From the fair clime where first I breathed this air,
Yet know I bear a Kingdom in this sword,
And ere I die, look to behold this Front
Impaled and circled with a royal Crown.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I never marked this Gallant half so much:
He hath my brothers eye, my fathers brow,
And he is Eustace all from top to toe.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: I had a sister, Lady, with that red,
That gives a crimson tincture to your cheek,
With such a hand hid in a glove of snow,
That spake all music, like your heavenly tongue;
And for her sake, fair Saint, I honour you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I had a brother, had not the rude seas
Deprived me of him, with that manly look,
That grace, that courage, I behold in you.
A Prince, whom had the rude seas never seen,
Even such another had young Eustace been.

sp.speaker: Evs.
sp.l: Eustace! even such an accent gave her tongue,
So did my name sound in my sisters mouth,
O Bella Franca, wert thou not obscured
Within a cloud and mask of poverty,
Such fame ere this had thy rare virtues won,
Thus had thy beauty checked the all-seeing Sun.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: It is my brother Eustace.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: View her well.
Imagine her but thus attired, and she
Would Bella Franca, and my sister be.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: But strip my brother from his Prentice cote,
His cap, his common soldiers base disguise:
Even such a Gallant as this seems to me,
Such would my brother, my sweet Eustace be.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Sister!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Brother!

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Make me immortal then, by heaven I vow,
I am richer than the Persian Sophy now.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: All Asia flows not with more plenteous treasure,
Than I, to embrace my brother, my hearts pleasure.
How did you scape the waves?

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: How have you past
The perilous Land, and crossed the Seas so vast?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Where are my brothers, Eustace?

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: O, those words,
Pierce to my heart like Darts, and pointed swords,
Omit these passions, sister, they are dead.
But to forget these griefs, what youth is this?

sp.speaker: Fren. Lad.
sp.l: Page to the Prince of France.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: It is he I hate,
As chief occasion of my banishment.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yet, my sweet brother, do not blame the youth,
Full well he hath demeaned himself with me.
He never, since we entered in these woods,
Left me in my distress; when we alone
Sit in these deserts never by rude force
Did do me the least shame, or violence.

sp.speaker: Fren. Lad.
sp.l: A good cause why I lead so chaste a life,
A jealous man may trust me with his wife.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Well, sirrah, for your truth and honesty
I pardon thee, though I detest thy Lord.

sp.speaker: Fren. Lad.
sp.l: Then let me change my habit, gentle sir,
Least in this shape I chance to meet my Master.
Then, if you please, I will cloth me like a Lady,
And wait upon your sister in your Tent.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Nay, if it please thee; I am well content.

sp.speaker: Fren. Lad.
sp.l: My plot is good; well, howsoever it prove,
It will either end my life, or win my love.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Come, best part of myself, we now will go
To wail our fortunes, and discourse our woe.
I will disguised unto the famous siege,
And in these Arms make known my valours proof:
You shall in secret in my Tent abide.
I to achieve fame will my spirits employ,
After this grief my heart divines much joy.

div2.stage: Exit. Enter Robert, and Tancred, Godfrey, and Charles, with their Shields and Scutchions, Drumme and Souldiers, Godfreyes Shield, hauing a Maidenhead with a Crowne in it, Charles his Shield the Haberdashers Armes.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Behold the high walls of Jerusalem,
Which Titus and Uespasian once brake down:
From off these Turrets have the ancient Jews
Seen worlds of people mustering on these Plains.
O Princes, which of all your eyes are dry,
To look upon this Temple, now destroyed.
Yonder did stand the great Iehovahs House,
In midst of all his people, there he dwelt:
Vessels of gold did serve his Sacrifice,
And with him for the people spake the Priests.
There was the Ark, the Show-bread, Aarons Rod,
Sanctum, Sanctorum, and the Cherubines.
Now in that holy place, where God himself
Was personally present, Pagans dwell.
False Gods are reared, each Temple Idols bears.
O who can see this, and abstain from tears?

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: This way, this sacred path our Saviour trod,
When he came riding to Jerusalem,
Whilst the religious people spread his way
With flowers, and garments, and Hosanna cried.
Yonder did stand the great Church, where he taught,
Confuting all the Scribes and Pharisees.
This place did witness all his miracles:
Within this place did stand the judgment seat,
Where Pontius Pilate with the Elders sate,
Where they condemned him to be whipped and crowned,
To be derided, mocked, and crucified,
His hands bored through with nails, his side with Spears.
O, who can see this place, and keep his tears?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: On yond side of the Town he died for us:
At whose departure all these walls did shake,
And the destroyed Temples vail did rend:
The groves are to be seen, from which Ghosts rose,
There stood the Cross, there stands the Sepulchre:
The place still bears the name of Dead men's bones.
And still the Tomb our Saviours Livery wears.
What eye can see it, and not melt in tears?

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: No soldier but shall look with reverence
Upon these fair and glorious Monuments.
To swear, or speak profanely, shall be death.
I cast my heart as low as to this earth,
And wish that I could march upon my knees,
In true submission, and right holy zeal.
O since our wars are Gods, abandon fears,
But in contrition weep repentant tears.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Sound a Parley; I see your hearts are fired,
Your souls with victory from heaven inspired.

div2.stage: Sound a Parlee. Enter vpon the walles, Soldan, Sophy, Tvrnvs, Morates. Souldiours. Flourish.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Why swarm these Christians to our City walls?
Look (foreigners) do not not the lofty Spires,
And these cloud-kissing Turrets that you see,
Strike deadly terror in your wounded souls?
Go Persian, flourish my vermilion flag,
Advance my Standard high, the sight whereof
Will drive these stragglers in disordered ranks,
And in a hurly burly throng them hence.

sp.speaker: Per. Sop.
sp.l: See how they quake, to view our martial looks!
As when a sturdy Cyclops rears aloft
A boisterous Truncheon amongst a troupe of Dwarfs.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: Sultan and Sophy, ye damned hell-hounds both,
So quakes the Eagle to behold a gnat,
The Lion to behold a Marmoset.
I will beard and brave you in your own belief,
As when the heathen God, whom you call Jove,
Warred with the Giant, great Enceladus,
And flung him from Olympus two-topped Mount
The swains stood trembling to behold his fall,
That with his weight did make the earth to groan.
So, Sultan, look, when I have scaled these walls,
And won the place where now thou standest secure,
To be hurled head-long from the proudest Tower,
In scorn of thee, thy false gods, and their power.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: We will assail you like rebounding Rocks,
Bandied against the battlements of heaven:
We will turn thy City into desert plains:
And thy proud Spires that seems to kiss the Clouds,
Shall with their guilt-tops pave the miry streets,
As all too base for us to march upon
Seest thou this shield, how ever this device
Seems not to rank with Emperors; Sultan, know
This shield shall give thy fatal overthrow.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Such peals of Thunder did I never hear,
I think that very words these walls will tear.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: This shield you see, includes two mysteries;
A Virgin crowned it is the Mercers Arms,
Withal the picture of my love that is fled.
Both these I will grace, and add to them thy head.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Methinks I see pale death fly from their words:
Their speech so strong; how powerful are their swords!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Since first I bore this shield I quartered it
With this red Lion, whom I singly once
Slew in the Forest; thus much have I already
Added unto the Haberdashers Arms.
But ere I leave these fair Judean Bounds,
Unto this Lion I will add all your Crowns.

sp.speaker: Tvr.
sp.l: Send for some prisoners, martyr, torture them
Even in the face of all the Christian Host.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: It shall be so Moretes, bring them forth.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: o drop of blood falls from a Christian heart,
But thy hearts blood shall ransom.

div2.stage: Enter some bringing forth old Bullen, and other prisoners bound.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Bring them forth,
Devise new tortures:
O for some rare Artist,
That could invent a death more terrible
Than are the everlasting pangs of hell.

sp.speaker: Old Bvl.
sp.l: O brethren, let not me move you to ruth:
Happy is he that suffers for the truth.
The joys to come exceed the present grief;
Secure yourselves, for Christ is my relief.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: Why shrinks the warm blood from my troubled heart?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Why starts my hair up at this heavy sight?

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: Say father, are not you the Bullen Earl?

sp.speaker: Old B.
sp.l: Fair son , I was the happen Bullen Earl:
But now my son

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Call no man son but me.
Father, my sword shall win you liberty.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: Peace forged Bastard whatsoever thou be:
My reverend father, call none son but me,
For in this sword doth rest thy liberty.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Such mercy, as my sword affords to Pagans,
He finds that calls me bastard; I am Charles,
Father you know me since I rescued you,
I am your only son, the rest are dead.

sp.speaker: Old Bvl.
sp.l: I know thee Charles.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: But father, I am Godfrey;
That by my valour have regained your right:
Have got your Dukedom from the insulting French,
And am myself invested Bullens Duke.

sp.speaker: Old B.
sp.l: I know thee Godfrey.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Godfrey!

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: Brother Charles!
The confident assurance of thy death,
Made me to give the lie to my own thoughts.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: The selfsame strong opinion blinded me,
Else for my brother I had challenged thee:
Brother, you might have known me by the Arms
Which I have borne in honour of my Trade.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: Ah, but the resolution of thy death
Made me to lose such thought.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Let us rejoice,
And to your plausive fortunes give our voice.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: Prince Robert, did the time afford us leave,
We would discourse the sum of our escapes:
But to our fathers rescue.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Yield him slaves.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Tush, we will keep him spite of all your braves.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: Be that our quarrel.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: With courage, courage strives,
We fight for Christ, our father, and our lives.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Here stands my Ensign, and by it a Crown,
That you shall know the Persian honourable,
He that can fetch this Ensign from the walls,
(Which I myself will guard) and leave some token
Behind him, that his sword hath conquered it,
He shall enjoy them both.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: And here stands mine,
sp.stage: Set vp his Standard and Crowne.
sp.l: The Babylonian Emperors royal Standard.
By it I plant the rich Cicilian Crown,
Guarded by me and my all-conquering troupes.
He that but leaves a note he hath been here,
And scapes unslain, although he win them not,
That Christian will I honour.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Drums, alarum.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: As loud and proud defiance our Drum sounds.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: For Christ, my father, conquest, and two Crowns.

div2.stage: Exeunt. Alarum. The Christians are repulst. Enter at two seuerall dores, Gvy and Evstace climbe vp the wals, beate the Pagans, take away the Crownes on their heads, and in the stead hang vp the contrary Shields, and bring away the Ensignes, flourishing them, seuerall wayes. Enter Soldan, Sophy, Moretes, Tvrnvs, with Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Now the first wall is won, the Ensigns seized,
The Crowns surprised, the Christians have the day:
What shall we leave the Town?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Aye, leave the Town.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: It is best, it is best to take us to the field.

sp.speaker: Tvr.
sp.l: I think it is best that we make good the breach,
And have no thought of marching towards the field:
We leave a place of much security.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Why then make good the breach,

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: It shall be so.
Gather our forces to make good the breach.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Tush, why should we be pent up in a Town?
Let us ope the gates and boldly issue out,
Leaving some few Pikes to make good the breach.
What say you Lords?

sp.speaker: Lords
sp.l: Then let us issue out.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Set ope the gates, and let us issue out.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: And so expose us to the general spoil.
Keep the gates shut, defend them manfully.
These Christians fight like devils; keep fast the gates,
And once again let us make good the wall.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Make good the walls, make good the walls.

div2.stage: Enter at one dore Robert and Charles, they meete Evstace with his Trophee: Enter at another dore Godfrey Tancred, they meete Gvy with his Trophee.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Triumphant honour hovers over our Arms
What gallant spirit bravely hath borne hence
The Emperors Standard, slaughtered his proud Guard,
And in the steed thereof hung up his Shield?

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Witness this royal Crown upon my head,
I seized the Ensign, I hung up that Shield.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: What puissant arm snatched hence the Sophies Standard?

sp.speaker: Gvy.
sp.l: This Crown upon my head, says it was I.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Forgetful Charles, brave Robert see the Knight,
Whose valour freed us from the Sultans hands.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Renowned Christian, ever honoured be,
It was thy sword procured us liberty.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: By heaven not I, I never came in place,
Where Robert or that Gallant were distressed:
But there are others thankless, whom I freed,
And now too proud forget that honoured deed.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: It was he released us ; honoured stranger thanks,
But they are idle offerings from true hearts.
Prince Tancred and myself, owe thee our lives.

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: You mock me Princes, never did my sword
Drink drop of Pagans blood to set you free:
But Robert and that Prince unthankful be.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Whose shield is that?

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Mine.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Then to you we owe
Thanks for our lives, the Pagans overthrow.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: The shield I challenge, but the act deny,
I never gave you life or liberty.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: Whose shield is that?

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: Mine.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: Then by thee we live ,
Thou didst our desperate lives and freedom give.

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: What mean you Princes to deride a stranger?
These eyes did never see you two in danger.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Who owes that shield?

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: I: and who owes that?

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Gvy.
sp.l: Thou knowest me then.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Thanks fortune, that I do.

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: Have at thee slave.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Brave foe have at thee too.

div2.stage: Fight, and are parted by the Princes.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: What ere your quarrel be, contend no more
He draws his sword against me that fights again:
For I am foe to all dissension.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: So are we all, then end these wars in words,
The Pagans have employment for your swords.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: For one blow more, take here my Crown amongst you,
Now that my spleen is up, it will not down,
I will give you all I have for one bout more.

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: Lords, take mine too: by heaven I will pawn my life
Against the Sultans head, to bring it you,
So you will let us try this mastery.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Kingdoms nor Crowns can hire it at our hands,
It shall not be, we say it shall not be.
What are you Lords? we charge you by his honour
Whom in your outward habit you profess,
To tell us both what and from whence ye are.

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: You charge us deeply. I a banished man,
Whom you for mutiny expulsed the Camp,
Yet was I leader of ten thousand French,
But thought by you unworthy of these wars.
Since my exile (Prince Robert view me well)
I freed you two from base captivity.
It was I that brought you weapons in the woods,
And then you termed me some Celestial power,
But being now in safety, you forget
Your dangers past, and cancel that great debt.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Nay I am sure you long to know me too.
I am your outlaw brother, one of your Leaders,
Banished with him: that from the Persians rage
Freed Tancred, and that valiant man at Arms;
How ever now they can forget my prowess.
What need you more, I am he that won this Crown,
And from these high walls plucked that Ensign down.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: You have redeemed all your offences past,
Deserving best in this society:
But when you freed me, you did bear that shield.

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: I did, but since exchanged it with my foe.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: And you did bear that shield.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: True, I did so.
Ah had I been awake, thou knowest my mind,
Thou hadst writ thy ruin in blood.

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: Thy words are mine.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Leave brother Godfrey, and the Bullen Duke.

sp.speaker: Evs.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: What!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Do you not know these faces?

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: Brother Charles.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Brother!

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: Charles!

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: I will question with them, for may it not be
The might escape the seas as well as we?
I had a brother, sir, resembled you.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: I had a brother too resembled you:

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: The Bullen Duke, if ever you have heard
Of such a man, had once a son like you.

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: aye, and another son as much like you.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: My brothers name was Eustace.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Godfrey mine.

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: That Duke called his son Charles.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Mine called his Guy.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: My brother Eustace!

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Godfrey!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Guy!

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: And Charles!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Brothers!

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: This accident breeds wonders in my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: O let me curse that head that envied thee.

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: Nay curse my heart that emulated thee.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: My brother outlaw, and my own true brother!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: For ever thus let us embrace each other.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: When I was cast upon the Bullen Strand,
I thought none had escaped the seas but I.

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: When I was thrown upon the French Kings Coast,
I thought none had escaped the Seas but I.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I thought the seas had favoured none but me,
When I attained the shores of Italy.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Ireland took me, and there I first touched ground,
Presuming that my brothers all were drowned.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Were ye the four young London Prentices,
That in the ships were wracked on Goodwins sands?
Were said to have perished then of no repute?
Now come the least of you to lead an Host,
And to be found the sons to a great Duke?

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: Witness my shield the Trade I have professed.

sp.speaker: Gvy.
sp.l: Witness my shield I am one amongst the rest.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Witness thou mine.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: And witness thou for me.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: We witness all your martial chivalry.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: And now my foe turned brother, end our hate,
And praise that Power Divine who guides our state.

sp.speaker: Gvy.
sp.l: Divide we hands and hearts: what hatred rests,
Pour out in Thunder on the Pagans crests.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Our joys are not at full, they shall not yet
Know where my sister and their love remains,
Until these wars have end. O had our God
Not laid our fortunes open, but a brother
Been brought in triumph to a sisters bed,
Clouds of despair had masked our Sun of joy.
Yet will I keep her secret, and the rather,
To crown our haps when we have freed our father.

div2.stage: Enter Tvrnvs.

sp.speaker: Tvr.
sp.l: Christians once more defiance in my tongue,
Sounds dismal terror in your fearful ears.
The Princes whom I serve, grieve they have mured
Such an huge Army in a wall of stone,
And they are thus resolved;
To leave all place of scorned advantages,
And in a pitched field end this glorious war.
Say, will ye meet them?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Though he trust his strength,
Yet will we meet his forces face to face,
When the dry earth shall quaff your bloods apace.

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: And tell the Sultan from a Christian Prince,
That won from him these colours, and this Crown,
In that pitched field my head this Crown shall bear,
And scarf-like these athwart my breast I will wear.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: This for the Persian's sake I will wear in sight,
And under his own ensign this day fight.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Go tell the Sultan that he wears my Crown.
Fortune hath given it me, it is mine own.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: If thou hast more to say concerning war,
Omit thy braves and trifling circumstance:
We will meet you sooner than you can desire.
Be gone, be gone, our hearts are all on fire.

sp.speaker: Tvr.
sp.l: Brave Lords, our conquests will be honourable,
Because we have to deal with honoured foes:
Our pikes stand to receive you like a wood,
We will flake our white steeds in your Christian blood.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Prepare to meet them, and appoint our powers,
This day the City and themselves are ours.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Thou under whom we fight, this day defend us,
For unto thy protection we commend us.

div2.stage: Exeunt. Enter at one dore with Drum and Colours, Soldan Sophie, Moretes, Tvrnvs, and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Great Monarchs, Kings, and Princes of the East,
Ye come to encounter with a valiant foe;
Such as have swam huge Rivers, climbed the Alps;
That can endure sharpe hunger; such as shrink not
To have their bloods sod with the dog-days heat,
Nor to be cruddled with cold Saturn's rod.
What honour were it for an Host of Giants,
To combat with a Pygmy Nation?
No, Lords, the foe we must encounter with,
Is full of spirit and majestic spleen,
Strong, hardy, and their hearts invincible.
Destroy these, and you win yourselves a name,
And all the nations of the earth shall fear you.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: The more renowned the foe is, the more famous
Shall be our conquest, the more great their fall.
Come Lords, divide we our battalions.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Be yours the Forward.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: I will give the charge.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Turnus, have you the Rearward, I the battle,
Moretes, thou this day shalt lead the horse
Take thou the Cornet, Turnus thou the Archers,
Be thine the Guidon, I the men at Arms
Be mine this Ensign.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Then mount our Canons, let our flanking pieces
Rail on the Christian Army with wide mouths.
For I this day will lead the forlorn hope,
The Camisado shall be given by me.

sp.speaker: Tvr.
sp.l: Already they have placed their battery,
Their Ordinance stand fit to beat the Flanks.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: My Cannoneers need no instruction.
Come, let us line our Pikes with Musketeers,
And so attend the Christians fatal charge.

div2.stage: Enter marching, Robert, Tancred, Godfrey, Gvy, Charles, Evstace, Drumme and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Princes, this day we are espoused to death:
A better place to die in, than this vale,
In which our Saviours Sepulchre remains,
What man in all our Army could desire?
Speak, how have you disposed our Officers.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: Your Grace is Captain General of the Army.

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: And Godfrey you high Marshall, and Master of the Camp,
And as assistants you have under you
The Sergeant Mayor, Quartermaster, Provost,
And Captain of the Spyons.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: My brother Guy chief General of the Horse
To serve him his Lieutenant Colonel
Captains and Scoutmasters.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: My brother Charles General of the Artillery,
Under him his Lieutenant commissaries of Munitions,
Gentlemen of the Artillery, Colonel of Pioneers,
Trench Masters, and carriage Masters.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: My brother Eustace Treasurer of the Camp,
And under him the Auditors, muster-masters, and Commissaries.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Prince Tancred is our Royal Secretary,
Without whom nothing is concluded on.
Thus are the special Offices disposed.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Princes, what order take you for the assault.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: One half maintain the battery beat the walls,
Whilst the other keeps them play in the open fields.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: We shall not need to block the breach with Forts,
Victuals and forage are at pleasure ours.
Stockadoes, Palizadoes, stop their waters.
Bulwarks and Curtains all are battered down
And we are safe entrenched by Pioneers.
Our Case-mates, Cavaliers, and Counterscarps,
Are well surveyed by all our Engineers.
Fortifications, Ramparts, Parapets;
That we at pleasure may assault the way,
Which leads unto the gate Antiochia.

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: Whilst you intend the walls, shall my bard horse
Give a brave onset, shivering all their Pikes,
Armed with their Grieves and Maces, and broad Swords,
Proof Cuiraces, and open Burganets.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Yet let us look our battle be well manned,
With shot, Bills, Halberds, and proof Targetiers.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: No man but knows his charge. Brothers and friends,
See where they stand for us ; this night shall hide
All their bright glory which now swells with pride.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Christians?

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Pagans?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Behold our Camp.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Sultan, survey ours too.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: From Ganges to the Bay of Calecut,
From Turkey and the threefold Arabie:
From Sauxin Eastward unto Nubia's bounds,
From Lybia and the Land of Mauritans,
And from the red Sea to the wilderness,
have we unpeopled Kingdoms for these wars,
To be revenged on you base Christians.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: From England, the best brood of martial spirits,
Whose walls the Ocean washeth white as snow,
For which you strangers call it Albion:
From France, a Nation both renowned and feared,
From Scotland, Wales, even to the Irish Coast,
Beyond the pillars great Alcides reared,
At Gades in Spaine unto the Pyrene Hills,
Have we assembled men of dauntless spirits,
To scourge you hence ye damned Infidels.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Within our troupes are sturdy bands of Moors,
Of Babylonians, Persians, Bactrians,
Of Grecians, Russians, of Tartarians, Turks,
Even from the floods that grow from Paradise
Unto this place where the Brooke Kedron runs.

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: Within our Troupes are English, French, Scotch, Dutch,
Italians of Prince Tancred's Regiment.
Even from the Seas that wall in Albion,
As far as any River or Brooke runs,
That Christian drinks on, have we people here,

sp.speaker: Tvr.
sp.l: To make our streets red with your Christian blood.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: To drown you slaves in a vermilion flood.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: To burn your bodies over your Prophets grave.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: To lead you Emperor Captive like a slave.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: To make your guide trot by my chariot wheel.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: To lash your armour with these rods of steel.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Then to extirp you all, ye Persian powers,
Assist our courage, make the conquest ours.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: God match thy might with theirs, protect us too;
To let this people know what thou canst do.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: A charge, a charge, rail drums, and Cannons roar,
Christians, at home your friends abroad deplore.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: Christians at home abroad our conquests fame;
Thou God of Hosts this day make known thy name.

div2.stage: Alarum. Ioyne battell: The Christians are beaten off. The Soldan victoriously leades off his Souldiers marching. Enter Charles and Godfrey with Pistols.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: O God, that multitude should more than manhood,
That we should thus be borne down with a press,
Be thronged and shouldered from the place we keep!

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: For every man we lead, the foe hath ten,
Their weapons tops appear above their heads,
In as thick number as the spikes of grain
Upon a well tilled land: they have more lives,
Than all our tired arms could send to death,
If they should yield their bare breasts to our swords.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: What should we do? we are encompassed round,
Girded with thousand thousands in a ring.
And like a man left on a dangerous rock,
That waits the climbing tide rise to destroy him:
What way soever he looks, sees naught but death:
So we; the bloody tide grows up apace,
Whose waves will swallow us and all our race.
where is Guy and Eustace?

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: Gone to scale a Tower
In which our father lies: O I did see them
Cut down a wood of men upon the sudden.
Their swords cut lances, as a sith cuts grass:
Their valour seems to me miraculous.
Thou Saviour of the world, whose Cross we bear,
Infuse our hearts with courage, theirs with fear.

div2.stage: Exeunt. Enter Soldan, Sophie, and Souldiers. Alarum. Enter Gvy and Evstace with their father.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: A Syon, a Syon.

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: A Jerusalem.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: A father, and in him a Crown of joy.

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: A Syon, a Jerusalem, a father.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Through their Decurians, Centurions and Legions,
Captains of thousands, and ten thousands guards,
We have ventured even upon the Cannons mouth,
And scaled the bulwarks where their Ordinance played.
The strength of Armies triumphs in those Arms,
We have surprised the Fortress and the Hold:
My shield I have had cut piecemeal from mine arm.
But now you would have taken me for an Archer,
So many arrows were stuck here and here,
The Pagans thought to make a Quiver of me.
See brother, how the foe fresh forces gather!
A Syon, a Jerusalem, a father.

div2.stage: Euery one by turne takes vp their father, and carries him: Enter the two brothers, they aide and second them. And with a shout carry him away, Alarum: Enter Soldan, Sophie.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: An Engineer, call forth an Engineer.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Why, what to do, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: I will make these Turrets dance among the Clouds,
Before the Christians shall inhabit them.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Yet there is hope of conquest, fight brave Sultan.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: These Christians rage, like spirits conjured up,
Their thundering Ordinance spit huge clouds of fire,
They run against the walls like iron rams,
And bear them down afore them with their breasts.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Fortune thou art too envious of our glory,
Behold the two greatest Emperors of the earth,
The Babylonian Sultan, and great Sophy;
Unveil thine eyes, and look upon our falls.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Fortune and fate, and death, the devil and all,
Oppose themselves against us. Now what news?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Death.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: What news bringest thou?

sp.speaker: Tvr.
sp.l: Confusion,

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: That death was once my slave, but now my Lord.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Confusion was once page unto my sword.
Is the day lost?

sp.speaker: Tvr.
sp.l: Lost.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Must we needs despair?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Despair.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: We will not, we will die resolvedly,
The Palace we will make a slaughter-house,
The streets a Shambles, Kennels shall run blood,
Down from Mount Syon, with such hideous noise,
As when great showers of water falls from Hills.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Through which way did they make irruption first?

sp.speaker: Tvr.
sp.l: Through the gate, called Antiochia.
The selfsame breach that Roman Titus made,
When he destroyed this City, they burst ope.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: There is some virtue in the Cross they wear,
It makes them strong as Lions, swift as Roes.
Their resolutions make them Conquerors.
They have taken our Royal Standard from the walls,
In place whereof they have advanced their Cross.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: I will not I survive so foul a shame,
Once more unite our powers, (I mean ourselves )
For all powers else have failed us; bravely fight,
That our declining sun may make their night!

div2.stage: Enter the foure brethren.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Christians, base Christians, hear us when we call,
Eternal darkness shall confound you all.

div2.stage: Alarum. The foure brethren each of them kill a Pagan King, take of their Crownes, and exeunt: two one way, and two another way. Retrait. Enter Robert, Tancred, Godfrey, Gvy, Charles, Evstace, Old Duke, Drumme, Colours, and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Now smooth again the wrinkles of your brows,
And wash the blood from off your hands in milk:
With penitential praises laud our God,
Ascribe all glory to the heavenly Powers,
Since Syon and Jerusalem are ours.

sp.speaker: Tanc.
sp.l: We do abhor a heart puffed up with pride,
That attributes these conquests to our strength;
It was God that strengthened us and weakened them,
And gave us Syon and Jerusalem.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: Thou that dost muster Angels in the sky,
That in thyself hast power of victory:
Make thy name shine, bright as the noontide Sun,
Since Syon and Jerusalem are won.

sp.speaker: Old D.
sp.l: My former want hath now sufficient store,
For having seen this, I desire no more.
How fair and smooth my stream of pleasure runs,
To look at once on Syon and my sons!

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: Shores of abundance rain into our lips,
To make repentance grow within our hearts.
What greater earthly bliss could heaven pour down,
than Syon, our dear father, and this Town?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Then to confirm these conquests God hath given us,
Sealed with the blood of Kings and Imperious;
Let us elect a King, that may maintain
Our honours with the deaths of Monarchs slain.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Call forth the Patriarch of Jerusalem,
His right hand must bequeath that dignity.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: With tears I speak it, lagging in the train
Of the distressed Sultan he was slain.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Praised be our God, we have revenged his death.
Great Potentates consort him to his grave.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: What man, for gravity and sanctity,
May we think worthy of this honoured place?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Whose years, devotion, and most sacred life,
Better can fit that holy place, than his
Whose worthy sons have brought to end these wars?
Princes, join hands, invest him all at once.

div2.stage: Flourish.

sp.speaker: Old D.
sp.l: My fervent zeal, bids I should not deny:
It brings my soul to heaven before I die.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: But Princes, whom will ye elect the King,
To guard this City from succeeding peril.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: Robert of Normandy.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O chose Prince Tancred rather,

sp.speaker: Tanc.
sp.l: Too weak is my desert, and I refuse it.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Then put it to most voices.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Robert of Normandy.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Princes, we much commend you for your loves:
But letters from England tell me William is dead,
And by succession left the Crown to me.
I say Prince Godfrey hath deserved it best.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: So Tancred says.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: And so say all the rest.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: Princes, ye press me down with too much honours,
And load a soul that cannot bear them up.
Dissuade me not, no counsel I will hear.
Behold a Crown which Godfrey means to wear!
This made the blood run from our Saviours Brow
No Crown but this can Godfreyes heart allow.
Prayers are my pride, devotion draws my sword,
No pomp but this can Bullens soul afford.
My vow is irrevocable, state I refuse;
No other Crown but this will Godfrey choose.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: If he refuse the place, elect Prince Guy;
Most voices; shall he have the Sceptre?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Then Crown him straight, and henceforth let his name
Be through the world called Guy of Lessingham.
All these desire it, I consent with them;
Long live Prince Guy, King of Jerusalem.

div2.stage: Flourish:

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: The Crown is burst, and parted from my head;
I fear the heavens are angry with your choice.

sp.speaker: Old D.
sp.l: son Guy they are not. By Divine instinct
The heavens have lent me a Prophetic spirit.
This shows thy troublous reign, mutinies from far,
Shall fright thy Towns and Provinces with war.

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: If it be nothing else, Crown me again,
We have a heart our Kingdom to maintain.
What honours do my brothers heads await?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Prince Eustace, you shall wear this Crown of State,
Be King of Sicil and command that Isle.
Lord Charles, the crown of Cyprus longs to you,
That in the fight the King of Cyprus slew.
One general voice at once proclaim them Kings.

div2.stage: Flourish.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: In memory of this solemnity,
Here will I leave this Escutcheon borne by me:
That in what coast soever my bones be laid,
This shield may be an honour to my Trade.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Mine shall hang there, a trophy of my fame,
My Trade is famous by King Eustace name.

sp.speaker: Gvy.
sp.l: In memory a king hath borne this shield,
I add these Chalices to this Argent Field.

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: In honour of my first profession
That shield in all these wars by Godfrey borne,
I crown this Maids head with a wreath of Thorn.

sp.speaker: Old D.
sp.l: O were my daughter here this joy to see;
How light her soul! how glad would my heart be!

sp.speaker: Tanc.
sp.l: Would I had now my love.

sp.speaker: Gvy.
sp.l: Or I that Dame,
That adds to beauties sun a brighter flame.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Were the fair virgin here, I would renown
her glorious beauty with the English Crown.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Princes, I will fit you all, Lady come forth.

div2.stage: Enter Bella Franca.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: The lovely Princes.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Fair Mistress!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Lady!

sp.speaker: Godf.
sp.l: Madam!

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: Honoured Saint!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Nay pardon me, love comes not by constraint.
But Princes, will you grant me patience,
Before I part, I mean to please you all.
First holy Patriarch, tell me of all others,
Whom in the world you most desire to see.

sp.speaker: Old D.
sp.l: My daughter.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Prince Godfrey, Charles and Eustace, whom say you?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Next yourself our sister.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: And whom you?

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: My love.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Who is that?

sp.speaker: Tanc.
sp.l: Your honoured self fair Maid.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Nay, I will make good the words that I have said.
Father, I give a daughter to your hand:
Brothers, behold, here doth your sister stand.
Tancred behold the Lady you once ceased,
only I leave Prince Robert here displeased.

sp.speaker: Old D.
sp.l: My daughter Bella Franca!

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: Sister!

sp.speaker: Old D.
sp.l: I am too happy, and too full of joy.
Heaven powers on me more good than I can bear:
I that before was starved, now surfeit here.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Princes, and Lady, nothing can displease us ,
For we partake in all this glad content,
And with applause rejoice this accident.
Tancred rejoice, your love, and you your friends,
Where you begin with marriage, our love ends.
Kings, and kings Peers, to heaven ascribe the glory,
Whilst we to Chronicles report this story.

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: Make unto my sister! it is most strange,
Now Guy I would thy hadst thy French love here.
My heart should grant her what I then refused.
Now having got this state of dignity,
I grieve that I have so obdurate been,
But for amends would make her Syons Queen.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: And well remembered brother, I must now
Entreat you for a pretty boy your Page,
That hath on some occasion strayed from you.

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: O brother, where is the villain?

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Pardon him, and I will tell you.

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: Great were the offence, I would not clear for you.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: The poor boy, brother, stays within my Tent,
But so disguised you cannot know him now,
For he has turned wench: and but I know the wag,
To be a boy, to see him thus transformed,
I should have sworn he had been a wench indeed.

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: Pray let me see him, brother in that habit,
I would not lose the villain for more gold,
Than Syon would be sold for; he will blush
To be taken tardy in his Maids attire.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: You have pardoned him?

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: I have.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Then Jack appear:
Nay blush not to be in your woman's gear.

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: Leap heart, dance spirit, be merry jocund soul,
It is she undoubtedly.

sp.speaker: Fren. Lad.
sp.l: You know me then!

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: I do, it was that disguise,
That all this while hath blinded my clear eyes.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Fie, are you not ashamed to kiss a boy,
And in your arms to grasp him with such joy?

sp.speaker: Gv.
sp.l: She is no boy, you do mistake her quite.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: A boy, a Page, a wagtail by this light.
What say you sister?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Sure he told me so,
For if he be a maid, I made him one.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: Do not mistake the sex man, for he is none,
It is a rogue, a wag, his name is Jack,
A notable dissembling lad, a Crack.

sp.speaker: Gvy.
sp.l: Brother, it is you that are deceived in her,
Beshrew her, she hath been my bedfellow
A year and more, yet I had not the grace.
Brothers receive a sister; reverent father
Accept a daughter, whilst I take a wife,
And of a great Kings daughter make a Queen.
This is the beauteous virgin, the French Lady,
To whom my fortune still remains in debt.

sp.speaker: Evst.
sp.l: A Lady, then I cry you mercy brother,
A gallant Bride would I had such another.

sp.speaker: Fren. L.
sp.l: A wondrous change! she that your Page hath been
Is now at length transformed to be your Queen.
Pardon me Guy, my love drew me along,
No shameless lust.

sp.speaker: Gvy.
sp.l: Fair Saint, I did you wrong.
If fortune had not been your friend in this,
You had not lain thus long without a kiss.
Father, embrace her; brothers; sister, all.

sp.speaker: Old D.
sp.l: This fortune makes our joys mere comical.
The fame of our success all Europe rings:
The father, Patriarch, sees his sons all Kings.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: The heavens are full of bounty; then brave Princes,
First in the Temple hang these Trophies up,
As a remembrance of your fortunes past.
You good old father, wear your Patriarchs Robes,
Prince Godfrey, walk you with your Crown of Thorns;
Guy with his Lady; Tancred with his wife:
Charles with his Crown of Cyprus, and young Eustace
Crowned with the rich Sicilian Diadem;
I with the honour of the Pagans deaths.
So in Procession walk we to Christ's Tomb,
With humble hearts to pay our Pilgrims vows.
Repair we to our Countries, that once done,
For Syon and Jerusalem are won.

div2.stage: Exeunt Omnes.
